chapter.title: Issue Database Implementations
chapter.para:
In this chapter, we present two implementations of the &qmtrack; issue database.
The section describes an &idb; which uses &xml; as its storage format. Each issue is stored in an &xml;-formatted text file.
This implementation provides the following benefits:
Ease of implementation. &xml; input and output code developed to implement the &xml; export functionality of &qmtrack; can be used immediately to read and write the issue.
Editability. Expert users can modify the &idb; directly by editing the &xml; issue files. While we will in the long run discourage users from modifying the &idb; in this way, the ability to do so will be especially useful to &qmtrack; developers before the system is complete.
Transparency. It is conceivable that other tools will take advantage of a well-documented &xml; external format to manipulate the &idb; directly.
No additional software requirements. By including &xml; parsing and generating code directly in the &qmtrack; distribution, we will enable users to use this &idb; implementation "out of the box", without installing or configuring additional software.
The section describes an &idb; which uses an &sql; &rdbms; as its storage mechanism. Each issue is represented by a rows in one or more tables. The &sql; implementation relies on ordinary disk files as well for auxiliary storage, for such data as file attachment contents.
The &sql; implementation provides the following advantages:
Speed. &rdbms;s are optimized for high-speed storage and retrieval of data. A good &idb; implementation will take advantage of &rdbms; features such as indexing to speed up common operations.
Scalability. The efficiency and compactness of an &rdbms;'s data representation makes it suitable for very large deployments.
Integrity. Most &rdbms; systems provide mechanisms to preserve the database integrity in such eventualities as sudden system failure.

section.title: &xml; issue database
section.para: The &xml; &idb; implementation uses the canonical &xml; representation for issues described in section .

section.title: Issue files
section.para: Each issue is stored in a single &xml; file containing an <issue> element. All revisions of the issue are included in this file. The current revision is stored in full issue record format, with all fields included. Previous revisions are stored as difference issue records.
